Explanations about Options.-l(C): As a starting point, if you're confused on how to split up your disk, show the output of "fdisk -l /dev/sda" and explain what the currently existing partitions contain and how you want to reallocate space. It may be useful to check with "fdisk -l /dev/sdx" or "cat /proc/partitions" first. Have you been resizing partitions? Pending the output of "sudo fdisk -l /dev/sda" I wonder if the partition "/dev/sda3" as defined by the disk partition table (which fdisk will tell us) is 70.50 GiB, while the filesystem on the partition is only 25 GB.
Explanations about Options.-l(M):
List the partition tables for the specified devices and then exit. If no devices
 are given, those mentioned in /proc/partitions (if that file exists) are used.

Explanations about Options.-p(M):
Prints out a percentage completion bars for each resize2fs operation during an
 offline resize, so that the user can keep track of what the program is doing.

Explanations about Options.-l(M):
List the contents of the filesystem superblock, including the current values of the
 parameters that can be set via this program.

Answers.MP Summary: adjust tunable filesystem parameters on ext2/ext3/ext4 filesystems
Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_157788: How to find out how the filesystem was created?

Explanations about Options.-a(M):
All of the filesystems described in /proc/self/mountinfo (or in deprecated
 /etc/mtab) are unmounted, except the proc, devfs, devpts, sysfs, rpc_pipefs and
 nfsd filesystems. This list of the filesystems may be replaced by --types umount
 option.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Unmount all mounted filesystems (except the `proc` filesystem)
